ci_support_linux_64_r_base4.4.yaml:
cdt_name:
- conda
channel_sources:
- conda-forge
channel_targets:
- conda-forge main
cran_mirror:
- https://cran.r-project.org
docker_image:
- quay.io/condaforge/linux-anvil-x86_64:alma9
pin_run_as_build:
  r-base:
    min_pin: x.x
    max_pin: x.x
r_base:
- '4.4'
target_platform:
- linux-64

about.summary: Extend 'ggplot2' facets to panel layouts arranged in a grid with ragged edges. facet_ragged_rows() groups panels in rows of (potentially) varying lengths, facet_ragged_cols() does the same for columns. These can be useful, for example, to represent nested or partially crossed relationships between faceting variables.

Extend 'ggplot2' facets to panel layouts arranged in a grid with ragged edges. facet_ragged_rows() groups panels in rows of (potentially) varying lengths, facet_ragged_cols() does the same for columns. These can be useful, for example, to represent nested or partially crossed relationships between faceting variables.

name: r-ggragged
raw_meta_yaml:
{% set version = "0.2.0" %}
{% set posix = 'm2-' if win else '' %}

package:
  name: r-ggragged
  version: {{ version|replace("-", "_") }}

source:
  url:
    - {{ cran_mirror }}/src/contrib/ggragged_{{ version }}.tar.gz
    - {{ cran_mirror }}/src/contrib/Archive/ggragged/ggragged_{{ version }}.tar.gz
  sha256: feafd0025451230350ad1471634bbf06c6fdaa22965d6dbca51feca2199a272d

build:
  number: 1
  noarch: generic
  rpaths:
    - lib/R/lib/
    - lib/

requirements:
  build:
    - {{ posix }}zip               # [win]
    - cross-r-base {{ r_base }}    # [build_platform != target_platform]
  host:
    - r-base
    - r-ggplot2
    - r-gtable
    - r-rlang
    - r-vctrs
  run:
    - r-base
    - r-ggplot2
    - r-gtable
    - r-rlang
    - r-vctrs

test:
  commands:
    - $R -e "library('ggragged')"           # [not win]
    - "\"%R%\" -e \"library('ggragged')\""  # [win]

about:
  home: https://github.com/mikmart/ggragged, https://mikmart.github.io/ggragged/
  license: MIT
  summary: Extend 'ggplot2' facets to panel layouts arranged in a grid with ragged edges. facet_ragged_rows() groups panels in rows of (potentially) varying lengths, facet_ragged_cols() does the same for columns. These can be useful, for example, to represent nested or partially crossed relationships between faceting variables.
  license_family: MIT
  license_file:
    - {{ environ["PREFIX"] }}/lib/R/share/licenses/MIT
    - LICENSE

extra:
  recipe-maintainers:
    - conda-forge/r
